passage: Journalists have dubbed Gil Scott-Heron the "godfather of rap," a title that has appeared in hundreds of articles about him since the 1990s. Scott-Heron himself resisted the godfather ______ blank feeling that it didn't encapsulate his devotion to the broader African American blues music tradition as well as "bluesologist," the moniker he preferred.
question_text: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

answer_rationales.C: Choice C is the best answer. The convention being tested is punctuation use between a main clause and two supplementary elements. In this choice, the commas after "nickname" and "however" are correctly used to separate the supplementary adverb "however" from the main clause ("Scott-Heron…nickname") on one side and the supplementary participial phrase ("feeling…bluesologist") on the other.
answer_rationales.A: Choice A is incorrect because it fails to mark the boundary between the supplementary adverb "however" and the supplementary phrase ("feeling…bluesologist").
answer_rationales.B: Choice B is incorrect because a semicolon can't be used in this way to join the supplementary adverb "however" and the supplementary phrase ("feeling…bluesologist").
answer_rationales.D: Choice D is incorrect because a semicolon can't be used in this way to join the main clause ("Scott-Heron…nickname") and the supplementary word and phrase ("however" and "feeling…bluesologist"). Moreover, placing the semicolon after "nickname" illogically signals that the following information (Scott-Heron's feeling that the nickname didn't encapsulate his devotion to the blues tradition) is contrary to the information in the previous clause (Scott-Heron's resistance to the nickname).
